title.narrative: Principled, demand-driven grant-giving and capacity development.

description.narrative: The UNTF EVAW will continue to ensure that women and girls benefit from supported initiatives through improved access to essential specialist, safe and adequate services, including access to justice; transformed social norms, a key factor in preventing violence; and more effective legislation, policies and national action plans that include the participation and voices of women and girls in decision-making processes. Through these focused investments, the UNTF EVAW will continue to support efforts that enable civil society, and especially women’s rights organizations, to make progress towards achieving their goal of ending violence against women and girls.
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

title.narrative: More CSOs (especially WROs) are enabled through UN Trust Fund organisational support, accompaniment, and capacity development to be compliant with grant requirements and be resilient and adaptable organisations.
Percentage of new grantees that do not have (a) anti-fraud, (b) PSEA and (c) PSHA12 polices in place at the time of grant signing but do so within 12 months (per cycle).

description.narrative: (Proxy indicator for compliance with grant requirements)

title.narrative: Percentage of respondents to the Annual Grantee Survey that report a change in (a) organizational resilience* and/or (b) organizational adaptability* during the UNTF grant period
More CSOs (especially WROs) receive long-term funding from the UNTF appropriate to meet demand driven needs, project focus and approach.
Number/Proportion of small organizations awarded a grant in each cycle (subject to quality of the applications)
Number/Proportion of women's organizations awarded a grant in each cycle (subject to quality of the applications)
Number/Proportion of women-led organizations awarded a grant in each cycle (subject to quality of the applications)
Civil Society Organizations (especially women-led and women's organizations) are effectively supported to manage projects and replicate and scale-up results to EVAW/G.
Percentage of grantee respondents to the Annual Partner Survey who report that additional financing has been raised during the UNTF grant period

Percentage of respondents (to the Annual Partner Survey) who report confidence that securing a UN Trust Fund grant will enable their organisation to mobilize additional resources in the future for the current or future EVAW/G projects
Amount (in US Dollars) raised in additional financing for other EVAW/G projects (as reported by grantees in the Annual Partner Survey).
Amount (in US Dollars) raised in additional financing for the continuation or scale up of the project funded by the UNTF.

UNTF Secretariat supports grantees with tailored regional advice on EVAW project management and operations and efficiently manages the portfolio of grants and in order to achieve results, manage risks and learn lessons across the portfolio (by project, re

Percentage of grantee organizations partnering with research institutions and/or other partners on research and evidence gathering on EVAW/G during or after the project as a direct results of the UN Trust Fund
Number of platforms created for grantees' visibility and resource mobilization

comment.narrative: Increase in platforms that demonstrate evidence of increased visibility for UNTF grantees

title.narrative: Percentage of independent, external, final project evaluations produced which are assessed as satisfactory, good or very good in quality (in terms of evaluation methodologies) every 2 years and by cycle
Percentage of planned independent, external, final project evaluations (managed by grantees) that are produced every year
Civil Society Organizations and Government partners are effectively supported to implement EVAW/G projects across all regions
Percentage of grantee projects assessed as sustainable, according to evaluations
Percentage of grantee projects assessed as sustainable, according to evaluations
Percentage of respondents (to the Annual Partner Survey) who report joining or creating useful partnerships related to EVAW/G programming thanks to the UNTF grant
Percentage of grantee projects assessed as effective, according to independent evaluations
More CSOs (especially WROs) are enabled through UNTF programmatic support and capacity development to implement principled EVAW projects.

Percentage of respondents to the Annual Partner Survey who report receiving (up to 6 types of) advice or support from the UNTF Secretariat who were very satisfied or satisfied with the services provided (average grantee satisfaction rate)

Percentage of respondents to the Annual Partner Survey who attended either (a) physical or (b) online UN Trust Fund training that report the training as useful or very useful in the Annual Partner Survey

More CSOs (especially WROs) are enabled through UNTF organisational support, accompaniment and capacity development to be compliant with grant requirements and be resilient and adaptable organisations.
Percentage of grantee organization members trained that report retention and use of the learning in implementing the project after the workshop (post-training survey)
Percentage of grantees that have completed the compliance training.
Percentage of grantees that have completed the mandatory PSEA & PSHA training
More CSOs (especially WROs) are enabled through UNTF programmatic support and capacity development to implement principled EVAW projects

Percentage of active grantee projects in the portfolio that are rated for performance as good, satisfactory, needs improvement or poor over a six-month period (monitored every August and February, assessing performance from January-June and July to Decemb

Percentage of respondents to an Annual Grantee Survey that report an ability to implement projects according to EVAW programming principles (or not), disaggregated by programming principle of relevance to their project.
Number / Percentage of planned monitoring missions of UN Trust Fund projects that occur annually (disaggregated by region / type of mission etc)
More CSOs (especially WROs) receive long-term funding from the UN Trust Fund appropriate to meet demand driven needs, project focus and approach
Number/percentage of CSOs receiving “longer-term” grants (i.e. 4 or more years)
Number of CSOs with an active grant (3 or more years) from the UN Trust Fund, annually (disaggregated by type of CSO, especially WROs)
Number of CSOs awarded a new grant from the UN Trust Fund per cycle (Disaggregated by type of CSO, especially WROs)

description.narrative: (Similar to previous UNTF indicator 1.4) (Aligns with UNW indicator 0.5.d)
